title: 114_hr5173
content: The "Homeowners Access to Visitability Enhancements (HAVE) Act of 2016" allows for grants to make homes more visitable. The "Homeowners Access to Visitability Enhancements (HAVE) Act of 2016" authorizes the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to provide grants to low-income families for acquiring, constructing, retrofitting, or renovating visitable residences. Grants are limited to $5,000 per residence and only one grant per residence is allowed. The "Homeowners Access to Visitability Enhancements (HAVE) Act of 2016" authorizes grants for low-income families to acquire, construct, retrofit, or renovate primary residences. Unused grant amounts are recaptured after 1 year. Low-income families must submit applications to be eligible for grants. Low-income families must apply to the Secretary with details on how grant funds will be used for eligible activities and how it will make their residence meet visitability standards. The Secretary must report to Congress biennially on the grant program's progress. Grantees must provide necessary information for compliance with the Act. Definitions for "low-income family" and "residence" are provided in this section, specifying ownership requirements for dwelling units. This includes single-family residences, multiple-family residences, condominiums, and cooperative developments. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms like "Secretary" and "visitable" in relation to housing development. It also mentions the issuance of regulations by the Secretary within 180 days of the Act's enactment and authorization of appropriations. Authorization of Appropriations: $50,000,000 is authorized to be appropriated annually for fiscal years 2017 to 2022 to carry out the Act, with 50% allocated for grants for eligible activities under subsection (b) paragraphs (1) and (2), and the remaining 50% for eligible activities under paragraphs (3) and (4).
